comments:
Build ID: I20070601-1539

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Setup a C++ Project - empty, Linux gcc
2. Add a folder, click advanced, link to rse folder on a linux system
3. Goto Project settings
   C++ Build
   unset use default command (use make)
   unset generate Makefile automatically
   change build dir by clicking workspace... then navigate to the rse subdir previously added, click ok
4. Click Apply in the build settings dialog box and you get the error


More information:
I got this from the .log file:

Upgrading to blocker - as building a remote system is one of the things that the Europa release is attempting to address (as I understand it).

(In reply to comment #1)
> Upgrading to blocker - as building a remote system is one of the things that
> the Europa release is attempting to address (as I understand it).

There are known issues with this on the CDT. There are no "Europa" features. Feature work will be needed on the CDT to make this work.
The NPE has nothing to do with CDT specifically. The variable "workspace_loc" is defined by org.eclipse.debug.ui. I suggest moving this bug to Platform/Debug.

(In reply to comment #3)
> The NPE has nothing to do with CDT specifically. The variable "workspace_loc"
> is defined by org.eclipse.debug.ui. I suggest moving this bug to
> Platform/Debug.
I think you're right. Reassigning to platform..
*** Bug 191997 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The variable resolver returns:

resource.getLocation().toOSString()

but .getLocation() can return null. Marking as a 3.3.1 candidate.

Created an attachment (id=71182)
fix

we should be checking the location (IPath) prior to trying to convert it to OS format, as the location can be null

Having looked at the fix, I think that this will stop this NPE from coming out, but it will lead at least to an error saying - operation unavailable to the user or at most an NPE elsewhere. The real issue here is why getLocation() return null. The answer can be found in the documentation for the function: * If this resource is a project that does not exist in the workspace, * or a file or folder below such a project, this method returns * null. This method also returns null if called * on a resource that is not stored in the local file system. For such resources * {@link #getLocationURI()} should be used instead. Therefore I would have thought that the fix should be to call getLocationURI() if it can be determined that the location is on a remote system (via the rse).

A fix was applied to HEAD that uses getLocationURI(), see ResourceResolver.java.

This fix should be copied to 3.3.1 once we are able to do so.

Created an attachment (id=73354)
3.3.1 patch

patch for release to 3.3.1 maintenance branch
*** Bug 203483 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
